etymology.description: 木 ‘wood’ + 口 ‘mouth’—perhaps referring to the tastiness of its fruit; Shuowen: phono-semantic 木 (semantic) + 可 (phonetic), but considered unlikely.
etymology.interpretation: Combines the graph for a tree with a mouth to suggest something on a tree that is eaten, i.e., the apricot and its tree. An alternative Shuowen reading treats 可 as a phonetic, but modern scholarship generally rejects that analysis.

examples.chinese: 我买了两斤杏子(我買了兩斤杏子)。
examples.english: I bought two jin of apricots.

examples.chinese: 院里有一棵老杏树(院裡有一棵老杏樹)。
examples.pinyin: Yuàn li yǒu yì kē lǎo xìngshù.
examples.english: There is an old apricot tree in the yard.

examples.chinese: 这条围巾是杏色的(這條圍巾是杏色的)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè tiáo wéijīn shì xìngsè de.
